abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Amapa Sustainable
            Communities Project (ADAP) for Brazil were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was high, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: this is
            certainly not a new lesson, but the design of this project
            should have followed it. Packaging an urban and a rural
            development component, microcredit, enhancement of public
            administration and special treatment for selected groups
            into one rather small loan and putting that all into the
            hands of an inexperienced, weak agency should be avoided.
            Long delays between appraisal and project start-up may
            require revisiting and revising the project before or after
            signing/effectiveness. Three years passed between appraisal
            and startup of the project. Many things changed during that
            period, such as the disappearing of municipal forums, the
            diminishing importance and weakening structure of the
            executing agency, ADAP, the severe deterioration of AFAP
            (Amapa State Development Financing Agency), and the
            understanding of the nature and importance of the project.
            The long delay in getting to loan signing should have been
            understood as a signal of such changes happening. Avoiding
            stand-alone projects. Subprojects should be linked to and
            supported by local government and other programs of
            government and/or the private sector, thus creating
            synergies. Several well designed subprojects had their
            sustainability and impact negatively affected owing to the
            lack of such interaction. The discussion and selection of
            subproject ideas by communities and identification of a
            community takes time. Pressure to implement rapidly tends to
            leave little time between a call for proposals (CFP) and the
            deadline for submission. The first CFP under the project
            gave only 30 days for submission. This often tends to favor
            ideas and pet projects offered by well-meaning outsiders,
            without the necessary internal discussion, studies of
            markets, viability of technologies, etc., and without true
            ownership in the community. Organizations created
            specifically for participation in CFPs are not likely to
            come up with viable, sustainable proposals. The project
            should require that community agreement on a proposal be
            documented in the Minutes of a general assembly of their
            association. This was strengthened in the third CFP which
            required a minimum time of prior legal existence of an association.

6913962.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Urban development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Amapa Sustainable Communities
            Project aims to learn from Amazon-specific approaches, to
            reduce urban and rural poverty, through measures that are
            environmentally sustainable, economically efficient, and
            socially equitable. Overall project impact will be gauged by
            the extent to which useful lessons, both positive and
            negative, have been generated, and succeeded in improving
            the livelihood of urban and rural poor in Amapa. The project
            components include: 1) Urban community development
            sub-projects focusing on the poorest neighborhoods in the
            cities of Macapa, Santana, and Laranjal do Jari through the
            preparation, and implementation of community development
            plans. Sub-projects will address problems related to: low
            levels of community organization, lack of skills and
            educational opportunities, the absence of community
            planning, occupation of environmentally sensitive lands,
            poor sanitary conditions, and inadequate access to
            infrastructure and services. 2) Institutional strengthening
            for poverty reduction, will build the capacity of the state
            to address key issues of poverty, and development by
            supporting a specific reform of the state micro-credit
            provider, and a general reform of the state administrative
            apparatus in project-related areas. This will include
            support to the preparation of business plans, capacity
            building, and rural finance. 3) Rural community development
            sub-projects would build capacity in the rural areas, and
            provide grants for sub-projects that will be identified,
            developed, and managed by community, and producer
            associations. Two types of sub-projects will be financed:
            environmental and social infrastructure, and, support for
            environmentally-sustainable productive investments. 4)
            Capacity building for participatory management and technical
            assistance (TA) will reinforce the operational capacity of
            the Development Agency of Amapa State - ADAP - to coordinate
            project implementation; develop a project management
            information system; maintain a monitoring and evaluation
            system for the project, including close collaboration with
            the state Environment Secretariat (SEMA), and the national
            environmental protection agency (IBAMA); and, undertake
            information and promotional campaigns for public awareness.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Sustainable Communities (Amapa)
            Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP)
            supports the overall objectives of the Sustainable
            Communities (AMAPA) Project for Brazil which are to assist
            the government of the State of Amapa in improving the living
            conditions of the urban and rural poor, the most vulnerable
            groups and poverty reduction strategies throughout the
            state. The IPP recommendations are: 1) support for urban
            productivity and economic sustainable activities; 2) access
            to credit from local banks, social services and basic
            infrastructure; 3) technical assistance to local government
            communities and community organizations for participation in
            decision making of local municipal governments and state
            policies; and 4) institutional strengthening to the
            government of the state of Amapa. Among the poor people of
            the State of Amapa there is a Social Special Group of four
            communities that will receive special attention, they are:
            a) indigenous people; b) rural communities where women are
            responsible of the household; c) unemployed youth; and d)
            remnants of Quilombo (groups of slave decendants)
            inhabitants do Curiau in the surrounding of the city of Macapa.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Sustainable Communities - Amapa -
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Communities Project in
            the State of Amapa will implement environmental protection
            actions following an integrated analysis, ensuring that
            project invested resources, foster short-, medium- and
            long-term environmental, sustainable development. The
            project has been classified as Category B in accordance with
            the Bank's operational directives, given that overall,
            project related interventions will prod positive
            environmental impacts. Nonetheless, this environmental
            assessment looks at the potential adverse impacts resulting
            from subproject construction, and production processes,
            which may affect groundwater, and surface waters, due to
            excessive solid wastes, lubricants, and, sanitary and
            medical wastes, in addition to contamination due to
            indiscriminate disposal of fish residues along water
            courses, all of which potentially affecting ecosystems.
            Mitigation measures are as follows. Appropriate site
            selection should determine construction sites, to be located
            at a determined distance from water flows; septic tanks
            should be available to ensure best hygienic standards;
            treatment tanks would ensure the adequate disposal of
            residues; waste management, and effluent treatment would
            ensure the appropriate utilization of biodegradable
            materials, and residues for composting activities; drainage
            systems, and water supply and sanitation networks, should be
            inspected to ensure water quality, and sewage treatment;
            replanting of native species should be practiced to prevent
            soil erosion; and, appropriate fisheries management should
            include water quality control, determining as well the
            adequate amount of aquatic life, within an optimum organic environment.
